elements.content: The seven metal complexes, [Zn(L1)2] n (1), [Co(L2)(LA)] n (2), [Zn(L2)(LB)] n (3), [Cu(L2)(SO4)]2 (4), [Co2(L1)2Cl4] (5), [Co(L2)(LC)2] (6), and [Zn(L2)(NO3)2] (7) (L 1 = 2,2′-bis(benzimidazol-l-yl)ethylether, L 2 = 1,2-bis[2′-(benzimidazol-1-yl)ethoxy]ethane, L A = succinate, L B = terephthalate, and L C = 4-aminobenzoate) have been prepared by means of self-assemblies of Zn(II), Cu(II), or Co(II) salts, dibenzimidazolyl bidentate ligands with oligoether linkers, and organic acids (succinic acid (H2LA) for 2, terephthalic acid (H2LB) for 3, and 4-aminobenzoic acid (HLC) for 6). These complexes are structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction analyses. In complexes 1–3, one-dimensional (1D) polymeric chains are formed via metal centers and ligands. In complex 4, two 15-membered metallomacrocycles are connected by two sulfate groups to form a dimer. Complex 5 contains a 24-membered metallomacrocycle formed by two ligands and two Co(II) atoms. Each of complexes 6 and 7 contains a 15-membered metallomacrocycle formed by one ligand and one metal atom. In the crystal packings of complexes 1–7, two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular layers and three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular frameworks are formed via intermolecular weak interactions, including π–π interactions, hydrogen bonds, and C–H···π contacts. Additionally, the fluorescence emission spectra and quantum yields of ligands and metal complexes are described.

elements.content:
Seven zinc(II), cobalt(II), and copper(II) complexes based on dibenzimidazolyl bidentate ligands with oligoether linkers have been prepared and characterized.

Introdution

Recently, the rational design and assembly of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention in view of their intriguing crystalline architectures and potential applications as functional materials. In crystal engineering, the formation of coordination architecture mainly depends on the coordination geometry of metal ions and the nature of ligands. Besides, some weak interactions, such as aromatic π–π interactions, classical hydrogen bonds (such as N–H···O and N–H···N hydrogen bonds), and nonclassical hydrogen bonds (such as C–H···X hydrogen bonds, X = O, N, F, Cl, Br, and I) often affect the structures of complexes, and they can further link discrete subunits or low-dimentional entities into high-dimentional supramolecular networks. Nonrigid bidentate ligands are usually the typical building elements in the multidimensional networks. The conformational freedom nature of the flexible bidentate ligand modules may provide more possibility for the construction of unusual coordination frameworks. For example, some polyether ligands with phosphorus or nitrogen donor moieties as the ligating units connecting the metal have been described, in which the influences of the nature of ligands and canions on the formations of complexes have also been investigated. Ligands containing imidazolyl (or benzimidazolyl) rings play important roles in coordination chemistry, and they can coordinate with a variety of transition metals to form one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1D, 2D, and 3D) coordination compounds by using the nitrogen atom of imidazolyl (or benzimidazolyl). As a building block to construct some porous coordination polymers, organic diacid or acid (such as succinic acid, terephthalic acid, and 4-aminobenzoic acid) may form coordination architectures of diverse sizes and shapes together with bidentate ligands containing nitrogen donors. We are interested in dibenzimidazolyl bidentate ligands with oligoether linkers. We reported herein the preparation, structures, fluorescent emission spectra, and quantum yields of seven metal complexes, [Zn(L1)2] n (1), [Co(L2)(LA)] n (2), [Zn(L2)(LB)] n (3), [Cu(L2)(SO4)]2 (4), [Co2(L1)2Cl4] (5), [Co(L2)(LC)2] (6), and [Zn(L2)(NO3)2] (7) (L 1 = 2,2′-bis(benzimidazol-l-yl)ethylether, L 2 = 1,2-bis[2′-(benzimidazol-1-yl)ethoxy]ethane, L A = succinate, L B = terephthalate and L C = 4-aminobenzoate).

elements.content: Ligands 2,2′-bis(benzimidazol-l-yl)ethylether (L 1 ) and 1,2-bis[2′-(benzimidazol-1-yl)ethoxy]ethane (L 2 ) were prepared through the reaction of benzimidazole with 2,2′-diiodoethylether or 1,2-bis(2′-iodoethoxy)ethane, and they are obtained as white powders. The ligands L 1 and L 2 are soluble in common organic solvents (such as CH3OH, CH3CN, and DMF); therefore, crystallization of their complexes with inorganic metal salts occurs readily.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization of Ligands L1 and L2, and Metal Complexes 1-7 

Ligands 2,2'-bis(benzimidazol-l-yl)ethylether (L  1 ) and 1,2-bis[2'-(benzimidazol-1-yl)ethoxy]ethane (L  2 ) were prepared through the reaction of benzimidazole with 2,2'-diiodoethylether or 1,2-bis(2'-iodoethoxy)ethane, and they are obtained as white powders. The ligands L  1  and L  2  are soluble in common organic solvents (such as CH3OH, CH3CN, and DMF); therefore, crystallization of their complexes with inorganic metal salts occurs readily.

elements.content: Complexes [Zn(L1)2] n (1), [Cu(L2)(SO4)]2 (4), [Co2(L1)2Cl4] (5), and [Zn(L2)(NO3)2] (7) were prepared via the reaction of L 1 or L 2 with metal salts (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O for 1 and 7, CuSO4·5H2O for 4 and CoCl2·2H2O for 5) in CH3OH (or DMF/CH3OH). Complexes [Co(L2)(LA)] n (2), [Zn(L2)(LB)] n (3), and [Co(L2)(LC)2] (6) were prepared via the reaction of L 1 or L 2 , metal salts (CoCl2·2H2O for 2, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O for 3 and Co(NO3)2·6H2O for 6), and organic acid (succinic acid (H2LA) for 2, terephthalic acid (H2LB) for 3, and 4-aminobenzoic acid (HLC) for 6) in the presence of Et3N in DMF/CH3OH mixed solvent. The crystals of 1–7 suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown by evaporating slowly their CH3OH or DMF/CH3OH solution at room temperature. Complexes 1–7 are stable and can retain their structural integrity at room temperature for a considerable length of time.

Complexes [Co(L2)(LA)] n  (2), [Zn(L2)(LB)] n  (3), and [Co(L2)(LC)2] (6) were prepared via the reaction of L  1  or L  2 , metal salts (CoCl2⋅2H2O for 2, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O for 3 and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O for 6), and organic acid (succinic acid (H2LA) for 2, terephthalic acid (H2LB) for 3, and 4-aminobenzoic acid (HLC) for 6) in the presence of Et3N in DMF/CH3OH mixed solvent. elements.content: Analysis of crystal structure of 1 shows that a 1D polymeric chain is formed via 24-membered metallomacrocycle monomers, in which each monomer is constructed by two ligands L 1 and two Zn(II) atoms. Each Zn(II) center is surrounded by four nitrogen atoms from four ligand L 1 (Figure ) to afford a slightly distorted tetrahedron geometry. The distance of Zn–N bond ranges from 1.989(1) to 2.003(1) Å. The bond angle of N–Zn–N ranges from 106.1(7)° to 114.9(7)°. The neighboring Zn···Zn separation is 9.229(8) Å, and the angle of neighboring Zn···Zn···Zn is 160.8(1)°. These values are similar to those of known Zn(II) complexes. Around each Zn(II) center, opposite two couples of benzimidazole rings form the dihedral angles of 43.8° and 84.9°, and adjacent two benzimidazole rings form the dihedral angles of 71.7° and 88.5°. In each 24-membered metallomacrocycle, opposite two couples of benzimidazole rings are parallel to each other, and one couple contains π–π stacking interactions (the data of π–π interactions being given in ). In interval metallomacrocycles, the corresponding benzimidazole rings are parallel to each other.

Structure of Complexes 1-7 

Analysis of crystal structure of 1 shows that a 1D polymeric chain is formed via 24-membered metallomacrocycle monomers, in which each monomer is constructed by two ligands L  1  and two Zn(II) atoms. Each Zn(II) center is surrounded by four nitrogen atoms from four ligand L  1  (Figure ) to afford a slightly distorted tetrahedron geometry. The distance of Zn-N bond ranges from 1.989(1) to 2.003(1) Å. The bond angle of N-Zn-N ranges from 106.1(7)° to 114.9(7)°. The neighboring Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation is 9.229(8) Å, and the angle of neighboring Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn is 160.8(1)°. These values are similar to those of known Zn(II) complexes. Around each Zn(II) center, opposite two couples of benzimidazole rings form the dihedral angles of 43.8° and 84.9°, and adjacent two benzimidazole rings form the dihedral angles of 71.7° and 88.5°. In each 24-membered metallomacrocycle, opposite two couples of benzimidazole rings are parallel to each other, and one couple contains π-π stacking interactions (the data of π-π interactions being given in ). In interval metallomacrocycles, the corresponding benzimidazole rings are parallel to each other.

elements.content: Analyses of the crystal structure of complexes 2 and 3 show that their 1D polymeric chains are formed via 15-membered metallomacrocycles and organic acid groups as a bridge (succinate for 2 and terephthalate for 3) (Figures and ), in which each 15-membered metallomacrocycle is constructed by one bidentate ligand L 2 and one metal atom (Co(II) for 2 and Zn(II) for 3). The distinction between 2 and 3 is that all Co(II) atoms in 2 lie in a line (the angle of neighboring Co···Co···Co = 180°), whereas the molecular structure of 3 is the 1D zigzag polymeric chain with the Zn···Zn···Zn bond angle of 160.8(1)°. Besides, all ligands L 2 in 2 lie on the same side of the 1D polymeric chain, whereas invertal ligands L 2 in 3 lie on the same side of 1D polymeric chain. The two benzimidazole rings connected to the same metal center form the dihedral angle of 72.4(1)° for 2 and 86.6(1)° for 3.

elements.content: In 2, each Co(II) atom is surrounded by two nitrogen atoms from two benzimidazole rings, and four oxygen atoms (one oxygen atom is from water molecule and two oxygen atoms are from carboxyls) to adopt a slightly distort octahedral geometry. In the octahedral geometry, the axial positions are occupied by O(7) and N(1) with axial distances 2.163(1) and 2.177(1) Å. The axial position is slightly distorted, where the O(7)–Co(1)–N(1) angle is 175.9(7)°. Four N(3), O(3), O(4), and O(6A) atoms lie in the equatorial plane, and the distance of Co–O is from 2.058(1) Å to 2.276(1) Å and the distance of Co–N bond is 2.110(1) and 2.177(1) Å. The bond angles of N(3)–Co(1)–O(6A), N(3)–Co(1)–O(3), O(6A)–Co(1)–O(4), and O(3)–Co(1)–O(4) are 90.5(7)°, 98.9(7)°, 110.9(6)°, and 59.8(6)°, respectively. These values are similar to those of known Co(II) complexes. The adjacent Co···Co separation is 9.123(1) Å. All benzimidazole rings in same side of polymeric chain are parallel to each other. Notably, there exist two different coordination modes for two carboxyls in each succinate, and first carboxyl includes one monocoordinted oxygen and one uncoordinated oxygen, whereas second carboxyl includes two monocoordinted oxygens.

elements.content: Compared with 1, the neighboring Zn···Zn separation of 11.054(7) Å in 3 is longer than corresponding value in 1 (Zn···Zn separation = 9.229(8) Å for 1), and the bond angle of neighboring Zn···Zn···Zn of 160.8(1)° in 3 is larger than corresponding value in 1 (Zn···Zn···Zn angle = 114.4(1)° for 1). The coordination mode of Zn(II) center in 1 and 3 is similar. Each Zn(II) center in 3 is surrounded by four nitrogen atoms from four ligand L 1 to afford a slightly distorted tetrahedron geometry (Figure ). The distances of Zn–O and Zn–N bonds are from 1.923(1)–1.947(1) Å and from 2.015(2)–2.026(1) Å, respectively. The bond angles around Zn(II) center range from 99.3(9)° to 118.2(9)°. These values are similar to those of complex 1 and other known Zn(II) complexes. The two adjacent benzene rings from two terephthalates form the dihedral angle of 44.1(1)°. All interval benzene rings from terephthalates are parallel to each other. In all interval 15-membered macrocycles, the corresponding two groups of benzimidazole rings are parallel to each other, respectively. The same coordination modes exist for two carboxyls in each terephthalate, and each carboxyl includes one monocoordinted oxygen atom and one uncoordinated oxygen atom.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , two 15-membered rings of complex 4 are connected together by two SO4 2–, in which each 15-membered metallomacrocycle is constructed by one bidentate chalete ligand L 2 and one Cu(II) atom. In the molecule, an inversion center is observed. Each Cu(II) atom is penta-coordinated with two nitrogen atoms from two benzimidazole rings and three oxygen atoms from two sulfate groups to adopt a pentagonal pyramidal geometry, in which the axial positions are occupied by N(1) and O(6A) with axial distances of 1.931(7) and 1.982(5) Å. The axial position is distorted with an N(1)–Cu(1)–O(6A) angle of 164.0(3)°. The equatorial plane is formed by N(4), O(3), and O(5A) atoms. The distances of Cu(1)–N(4), Cu(1)–O(3), and Cu(1)–O(5A) are 1.977(7), 2.264(7), and 2.031(6) Å, respectively. The distance of Cu(1)–O(3) is longer than those of other Cu–O bonds. The bond angles of O(6A)–Cu(1)–O(5A), N(1)–Cu(1)–O(5A), N(4)–Cu(1)–O(6A), and N(1)–Cu(1)–N(4) are 70.1(2)°, 94.6(3)°, 97.7(2)°, and 94.7(3)°, respectively. Among four oxygen atoms of each sulfate, two oxygen atoms are connected to one Cu(II) atom, a third oxygen atom is bound to another Cu(II) atom, and a fourth oxygen atom is uncoordinated. Two sulfate groups and two Cu(II) atoms form an eight-membered ring, in which two planes Cu(1)–O(5A)–S(1A)–O(6A) and Cu(1A)–O(5)–S(1)–O(6) are nearly parallel with the dihedral angle of 3.2(4)°. The Cu···Cu sepataration is 4.477(3) Å. Those values are comparable with known metal complexes containing SO4. The dihedral angle between benzimidazole rings in the same ligand is 81.3(2)°, and the opposite two benzimidazole rings in different ligands are parallel.

elements.content: The X-ray crystal structural analysis of 5 shows that 24-membered metallomacrocycle are formed by two bidentate ligand L 1 and two Co(II) atoms as shown in Figure . In the molecule, an inversion center is observed. Different from 2, each Co(II) in 5 is tetra-coordinated with two chlorine atoms and two nitrogen atoms from two benzimidazole rings to adopt a slightly distorted tetrahedron geometry. The distances of Co–Cl and Co–N bonds are from 2.224(6)–2.248(6) Å and from 2.014(1)–2.022(1) Å, respectively. The six bond angles around the Co(II) center is in the range of 106.9(5)–115.2(5)°. These values are similar to those of complex 2. The Co···Co separation is 5.835(2) Å. The dihedral angle between two benzimidazole rings connected to the same Co(II) is 31.9°, and the dihedral angle between two benzimidazole rings in the same ligand is 61.9°. The dihedral angle between two benzimidazole rings of opposite angles is parallel. In addition, four intramolecular C–H···Cl hydrogen bonds are observed (the data of hydrogen bonds being given in ).

elements.content: In complexes 6 and 7, each 15-membered metallomacrocycle is formed by one bidentate ligand L 2 and one metal atom (Co(II) for 6 and Zn(II) for 7) as shown in Figures and . The two benzimidazole rings connected to one metal center form the dihedral angles of 66.5(1)° for 6 and 83.0(1)° for 7. In 6, the coordination mode of Co(II) atom is different from those of 2 and 5. Each Co(II) atom of 6 is hexa-coordinated with two nitrogen atoms from two benzimidazole rings and four oxygen atoms from two carboxyls to adopt a distorted octahedral geometry (Co(II) atoms of 2 and 5 being hepta-coordinated and tetra-coordinated, respectively). In 6, the bond distances of Co–O and Co–N are 1.995(4) and 2.073(4) Å, respectively. The bond angles around Co(II) center range from 97.3(2)° to 137.0(2)°. The two benzene rings from 4-aminobenzoate form the dihedron of 69.7(1)°. One benzene ring from 4-aminobenzoate and two benzimidazole rings form the dihedral angles of 37.9° and 82.9°, respectively.

elements.content:
In crystal packing of 7, 3D supramolecular frameworks is formed via C–H···O hydrogen bonds (). In C–H···O hydrogen bonds, the hydrogen atoms are from CH2, and oxygen atoms are from NO3 – anions.

The Conformations of the Complexes Formed via L<sub>1</sub> or L<sub>2</sub> and Metal Salts

The metal complexes formed via L 1 or L 2 and metal salts contain mainly two types of conformations, namely, the metallomacrocycle monomer and the polymer formed by metallomacrocycle monomer via suitable linkers (Schemes and ). However, the metallomacrocycle monomers via L 1 or L 2 and metal atoms are different, and the metallomacrocycle monomer I constructed by L 1 and metal atoms contains two metal atoms and two ligands (like complex 5) due to a relatively short ether chain, whereas the metallomacrocycle monomer III constructed by L 2 and metal atom contains one metal atom and one ligand (like complexes 6 and 7) due to a long ether chain. The metallomacrocycle monomers connected together by different bridging linkers can afford the dimer IV (like complex 4 using sulfate as bridge) or polymers II, V, and VI (such as complex 1 using M as bridge, complex 2 using succinate as bridge and complex 3 using terephthalate as bridge). Additionally, the arrangement of ligands in the polymer may have mainly two cases. One is that all ligands lie on same side of polymeric chain V (like complex 2), and another is that ligands lie on both sides of polymeric chain VI (like complex 3), and these diverse arrangements could be related to the property of linkers. Therefore, the conformations of metal complexes formed via L 1 or L 2 and metal atoms depend mainly on the length of ether chain, the structure of bridging linkers, as well as the types of anions and metal ions.

The metal complexes formed via L  1  or L  2  and metal salts contain mainly two types of conformations, namely, the metallomacrocycle monomer and the polymer formed by metallomacrocycle monomer via suitable linkers (Schemes  and ). However, the metallomacrocycle monomers via L  1  or L  2  and metal atoms are different, and the metallomacrocycle monomer I constructed by L  1  and metal atoms contains two metal atoms and two ligands (like complex 5) due to a relatively short ether chain, whereas the metallomacrocycle monomer III constructed by L  2  and metal atom contains one metal atom and one ligand (like complexes 6 and 7) due to a long ether chain. The metallomacrocycle monomers connected together by different bridging linkers can afford the dimer IV (like complex 4 using sulfate as bridge) or polymers II, V, and VI (such as complex 1 using M as bridge, complex 2 using succinate as bridge and complex 3 using terephthalate as bridge). Additionally, the arrangement of ligands in the polymer may have mainly two cases. One is that all ligands lie on same side of polymeric chain V (like complex 2), and another is that ligands lie on both sides of polymeric chain VI (like complex 3), and these diverse arrangements could be related to the property of linkers. Therefore, the conformations of metal complexes formed via L  1  or L  2  and metal atoms depend mainly on the length of ether chain, the structure of bridging linkers, as well as the types of anions and metal ions.

As indicated in Figure , the fluorescence emission spectra of ligands L 1 and L 2 , and complexes 1–7 in acetonitrile at room temperature are obtained upon excitation at 240 nm (the fluorescence emission spectrum of L 2 is similar to that of L 1 ). Ligand L 1 shows weak double emission bands centered at 305 and 335 nm, corresponding to intraligand transitions. Complexes 1–7 exhibit also double emission bands in the regions of 285–320 nm and 330–340 nm, but they are stronger than that of L 1 , which should originate from the metal perturbed intraligand processes.

Fluorescence Emission Spectra and Quantum Yields of Ligands L1 and L2, and Complexes 1-7 

As indicated in Figure , the fluorescence emission spectra of ligands L  1  and L  2 , and complexes 1-7 in acetonitrile at room temperature are obtained upon excitation at 240 nm (the fluorescence emission spectrum of L  2  is similar to that of L  1 ). Ligand L  1  shows weak double emission bands centered at 305 and 335 nm, corresponding to intraligand transitions. Complexes 1-7 exhibit also double emission bands in the regions of 285-320 nm and 330-340 nm, but they are stronger than that of L  1 , which should originate from the metal perturbed intraligand processes.

elements.content: The UV data, fluorescence data, and the fluorescence quantum yields of the ligands and complexes using the phenol and naphthalene as standard compounds are given in , respectively. The fluorescence quantum yields of the ligands and complexes were determined via the comparison with the quantum yield of phenol (Φ = 0.22) and naphthalene (Φ = 0.12) in acetonitrile solution at room temperature. The fluorescence quantum yields are calculated by the following formula: Φ u = Φ S × F u F S × A S A u where F u and F s are the integral area of fluorescence intensity of samples (ligands L 1 and L 2 , complexes 1–7) and standard compounds, respectively. A u and A s are absorption of samples and standard compounds at same wavelength in UV spectra. Φu and Φs are the fluorescence quantum yields of samples and standard compounds (Φs = 0.22 for phenol and Φs = 0.12 for naphthalene). The fluorescence quantum yields of ligands and complexes using different standard compounds (phenol and naphthalene) are similar (), which indicates the fluorescence quantum yields of these samples are accurate in the condition. The fluorescence quantum yields of complexes 1–7 are higher than ligands L 1 and L 2 , which may be ascribed to the incorporation of metal–ligand coordination interactions. The fluorescence quantum yields of complexes 3 and 4 (Φs = 0.26 for 3 and 0.28 for 4) are higher than those of complexes 1, 2, and 5–7 (Φs = 0.04–0.18), which shows that complexes 3 and 4 are expected to be used as candidates for potential photoactive materials.

elements.clean_text:
IR Spectra Analysis of 1-7 

In complexes 1-7, the absorption bands around 3000-2800 cm-1 can be assigned to aromatic υ(C-H) modes. The bands in the region 1687-1550 cm-1 may be ascribed to the CC stretching vibrations. The bands around 1615-1606 cm-1 may result from υ(CN) of benzimidazole rings. The strong absorption bands around 1300-1000 cm-1 originate from υ(C-O) of ether chains. The bands in the 1265-1200 cm-1 may result from υs(C-C) or υs(C-N) of benzene rings or imidazole rings. These values are similar to those of ligands. The strong bands at 3448-3431 for 2 and 4 should be ascribed to υ(O-H) of coordinated water molecules. The strong bands at 1606 for 2, 1611 for 3 and 1602 cm-1 for 6 are corresponding to υ(CO) of carboxyls. The middle absorption band at 3431 cm-1 for 6 is corresponding to υ(N-H) of amino groups.

elements.content: The seven Zn(II), Cu(II), and Co(II) complexes have been prepared and characterized. In complexes 2, 3, and 6, organic acids as ligands (succinic acid for 2, terephthalic acid for 3, and 4-aminobenzoic acid for 6) together with L 1 or L 2 participate in coordination with metal ions. In complexes 1–3, 1D polymeric chains are formed via metal centers and ligands. Complex 4 contains two 15-membered metallomacrocycles connected by two surfurate groups as bridges. Complex 5 contains a 24-membered metallomacrocycle formed by two ligands and two Co(II) atoms. Each of complexes 6 and 7 contains a 15-membered metallomacrocycles formed by one ligands and one metal atom. In the crystal packings of complexes 1–7, 2D supramolecular layers and 3D supramolecular frameworks are formed via intermolecular weak interactions, including π–π interactions, hydrogen bonds, and C–H···π contacts. The resultant structures of these complexes will provide valuable experimental data for crystal engineering and supramolecular chemistry. Additionally, the macrocyclic structures of these metal complexes suggest that they may have potential applications in the host–guest chemistry. Fluorescent emission spectra and quantum yields of ligands L 1 and L 2 , and complexes 1–7 are described. Further studies on new complexes from the precursors and analogous ligands are underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The seven Zn(II), Cu(II), and Co(II) complexes have been prepared and characterized. In complexes 2, 3, and 6, organic acids as ligands (succinic acid for 2, terephthalic acid for 3, and 4-aminobenzoic acid for 6) together with L  1  or L  2  participate in coordination with metal ions. In complexes 1-3, 1D polymeric chains are formed via metal centers and ligands. Complex 4 contains two 15-membered metallomacrocycles connected by two surfurate groups as bridges. Complex 5 contains a 24-membered metallomacrocycle formed by two ligands and two Co(II) atoms. Each of complexes 6 and 7 contains a 15-membered metallomacrocycles formed by one ligands and one metal atom. In the crystal packings of complexes 1-7, 2D supramolecular layers and 3D supramolecular frameworks are formed via intermolecular weak interactions, including π-π interactions, hydrogen bonds, and C-H⋅⋅⋅π contacts. The resultant structures of these complexes will provide valuable experimental data for crystal engineering and supramolecular chemistry. Additionally, the macrocyclic structures of these metal complexes suggest that they may have potential applications in the host-guest chemistry. Fluorescent emission spectra and quantum yields of ligands L  1  and L  2 , and complexes 1-7 are described. Further studies on new complexes from the precursors and analogous ligands are underway.

elements.content: 2,2′-Diiodoethylether and 1,2-bis(2′-iodoethoxy)ethane were prepared according to the literature methods. All the reagents for syntheses and analyses were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Melting points were determined with a Boetius Block apparatus. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Mercury Vx 400 spectrometer at 400 MHz. Chemical shifts, δ, were reported in ppm relative to the internal standard TMS for both 1H NMR, and J values were given in Hz. The elemental analyses of all compounds were obtained from the powder compounds recrystallized and measured using a Perkin-Elmer 2400C Elemental analyzer. IR spectra (KBr) were taken on an Bruker Equinox 55 spectrometer. The luminescent spectra were conducted on Cary eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. UV–vis spectra were obtained using a JASCO-V570 spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

2,2'-Diiodoethylether and 1,2-bis(2'-iodoethoxy)ethane were prepared according to the literature methods. All the reagents for syntheses and analyses were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Melting points were determined with a Boetius Block apparatus. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Mercury Vx 400 spectrometer at 400 MHz. Chemical shifts, δ, were reported in ppm relative to the internal standard TMS for both 1H NMR, and J values were given in Hz. The elemental analyses of all compounds were obtained from the powder compounds recrystallized and measured using a Perkin-Elmer 2400C Elemental analyzer. IR spectra (KBr) were taken on an Bruker Equinox 55 spectrometer. The luminescent spectra were conducted on Cary eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. UV-vis spectra were obtained using a JASCO-V570 spectrometer.

elements.content: A CH3CN (100 mL) solution of benzimidazole (1.590 g, 13.5 mmol), KOH (1.330 g, 20.2 mmol), and tetrabutylammonium bromide (0.130 g, 0.4 mmol) was stirred for 2 h under refluxing, and then 2,2′-diiodoethylether (1.987 g, 6.1 mmol) was slowly dropped to the above solution and stirred continually at 80 °C for 24 h. A pale yellow oil was obtained after filtrating and removing the solvent, and it was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (100 mL) and washed with water (3 × 100 mL). The organic layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4, After removing CH2Cl2, a white powder of 2,2′-bis(benzimidazol-l-yl)ethylether (L 1 ) was obtained. Yield: 1.510 g (81%). M.p.: 110–112 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHZ, DMSO-d 6): δ 3.68 (t, J = 6.4, 4H, CH 2), 4.25 (t, J = 6.4, 4H, CH 2), 7.31 (m, 6H, PhH), 7.82 (m, 4H, PhH or imiH) (imi = imidazole). elements.content: X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for complexes 1–7 were collected by using a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer at 296(2) K with Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω scan mode. There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection in all cases. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied by using SADABS, and the program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All structures were solved by direct methods by using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined with SHELXL by the full-matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. Hydrogen atoms bonded to C atoms were placed geometrically, and presumably solvent H atoms were first located in difference Fourier maps and then fixed in the calculated sites. Further details for crystallographic data and structural analysis are listed in Tables and . Figures were generated by using Crystal-Maker.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Determinations

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for complexes 1-7 were collected by using a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer at 296(2) K with Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω scan mode. There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection in all cases. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied by using SADABS, and the program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All structures were solved by direct methods by using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined with SHELXL by the full-matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. Hydrogen atoms bonded to C atoms were placed geometrically, and presumably solvent H atoms were first located in difference Fourier maps and then fixed in the calculated sites. Further details for crystallographic data and structural analysis are listed in Tables  and . Figures were generated by using Crystal-Maker.

This complex was prepared in a manner analogous to that of 2, and only succinic acid and CoCl2·2H2O were replaced with 4-aminobenzoic acid (82.3 mg, 0.3 mmol) and Co(NO3) 2·6H2O (0.175 g, 0.6 mmol), and purple single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained within two weeks. Yield: 0.120 g (53%) (based on L 2 ). M.p.: 274–276 °C. Anal. Calc. for C17H17Co0.5N3O3: C, 59.91; H, 5.03; N, 12.33%. Found: C, 59.83; H, 5.46; N, 12.72%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3431w, 2371w, 2030w, 1603m, 1557w, 1520m, 1466w, 1387vs, 1138w, 1100w, 1014w, 748m.

Preparation of [Zn(L<sub>2</sub>)(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>7</bold>)

This complex was prepared in a manner analogous to that of 4, only CuSO4·5H2O was replaced with Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.179 g, 0.6 mmol), and colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained within two weeks., Yield: 94.7 mg (63%). M.p.: 198–200 °C. Anal. Calc. for C20H22N6O8Zn: C, 44.50; H, 4.11; N, 15.57%. Found: C, 44.78; H, 4.51; N, 15.42%. cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of 2,2'-Bis(benzimidazol-l-yl)ethylether (L1)

A CH3CN (100 mL) solution of benzimidazole (1.590 g, 13.5 mmol), KOH (1.330 g, 20.2 mmol), and tetrabutylammonium bromide (0.130 g, 0.4 mmol) was stirred for 2 h under refluxing, and then 2,2'-diiodoethylether (1.987 g, 6.1 mmol) was slowly dropped to the above solution and stirred continually at 80 °C for 24 h. A pale yellow oil was obtained after filtrating and removing the solvent, and it was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (100 mL) and washed with water (3 × 100 mL). The organic layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4, After removing CH2Cl2, a white powder of 2,2'-bis(benzimidazol-l-yl)ethylether (L  1 ) was obtained. Yield: 1.510 g (81%). M.p.: 110-112 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHZ, DMSO-d 6): δ 3.68 (t, J = 6.4, 4H, CH 2), 4.25 (t, J = 6.4, 4H, CH 2), 7.31 (m, 6H, PhH), 7.82 (m, 4H, PhH or imiH) (imi = imidazole). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3084m, 3053w, 2948w, 2888m, 2860m, 1669s, 1615m, 1495vs, 1457s, 1435m, 1381s, 1359s, 1273s, 1210s, 1125s, 1061s, 1007w, 890m, 770m, 748vs, 707w, 643m, 479m.

Preparation of [Zn(L1)2] n  (1)

A methanol solution (10 mL) containing L  1  (0.100 g, 0.3 mmol) was added to a methanol solution (10 mL) of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.179 g, 0.6 mmol). The mixture was stirred for 30 min at about 40 °C. The filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly under ambient conditions, and colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained within two weeks. Yield: 81.6 mg (58%). m.p.: 240-242 °C. Anal. Calc. for C36H36N8O2Zn: C, 63.76; H, 5.35; N, 16.52%. Found: C, 63.44; H, 5.53; N, 16.77%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3440w, 3129w, 2913w, 2872w, 2358w, 2026w, 1615m, 1520s, 1478vs, 1383s, 1300vs, 1194m, 1126m, 1064w, 1010m, 927w, 811w, 744m, 714w, 632m.

Preparation of [Co(L2)(LA)] n  (2)

A N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution (5 mL) containing succinic acid (35.4 mg, 0.3 mmol) was added to a methanol solution (10 mL) of L  2  (0.100 g, 0.3 mmol). After ca. 3 min of vigorous mixing, an aqueous solution (5 mL) of CoCl2⋅2H2O (0.085 g, 0.7 mmol) was added and the pH value of the solution was adjusted to approximated 7 by triethylamine. The mixture was continually stirred for 30 min at about 40 °C. The filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly under ambient conditions, and purple single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained within two weeks. Yield: 84.3 mg (56%) (based on L  2 ). m.p.: 214-216 °C. Anal. Calc. for C24H26N4O6Co: C, 54.86.; H, 4.99; N, 10.66%. Found: C, 54.54.; H, 5.51; N, 10.32%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3448 m, 3154w, 2897w, 2030w, 1607s, 1507m, 1445m, 1391s, 1362w, 1300w, 1275w, 1259w, 1217m, 1192w, 1113m, 1013w, 931w, 811m, 773m, 753m, 748w, 661m.

Preparation of [Zn(L2)(LB)] n  (3)

This complex was prepared in a manner analogous to that of 2, only succinic acid and CoCl2⋅2H2O were replaced with terephthalic acid (50 mg, 0.3 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.179 g, 0.6 mmol), and colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained within two weeks. Yield: 0.119 g (62%) (based on L  2 ). m.p.: > 360 °C. Anal. Calc. for C56H52N8O12Zn2: C, 57.99; H, 4.52; N, 9.66%. Found: C, 57.72; H, 4.64; N, 9.34%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3432m, 3108w, 2909w, 2859w, 2026w, 1731w, 1611vs, 1516m, 1466m, 1354s, 1300w, 1279w, 1205w, 1142m, 1109m, 1022w, 918w, 819m, 748s, 636w, 574w, 507w.

Preparation of [Cu(L2)(SO4)]2 (4)

A DMF solution (10 mL) containing L  2  (0.100 g, 0.3 mmol) was added to a methanol solution (10 mL) of CuSO4⋅5H2O (0.150 mg, 0.6 mmol). The mixture was stirred for 30 min at about 40 °C. The filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly under ambient conditions, and blue single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained within two weeks. Yield: 0.105 g (64%). M.p.: 320-322 °C. Anal. Calc. for C40H44Cu2N8O12S2: C, 47.10; H, 4.35; N, 10.99%. Found: C, 47.48; H, 4.66; N, 10.71%.
